SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

org.sunspotworld.create
Interface IRobotCreate

public interface IRobotCreate

Interface that provides a high level interface to the iRobot series of Roomba/Create robots. The names of most of the sensors are derived mostly from the "Create Open Interface_v2.pdf" document found on the http://www.irobot.com site. Recommend reading this document in order to get a better understanding of how to work with the robot.

DEMO_ABORT

static final int DEMO_ABORT
See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_COVER

static final int DEMO_COVER
Create attempts to cover an entire room using a combination of behaviors, such as random bounce, wall following, and spiraling.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_COVER_AND_DOCK

static final int DEMO_COVER_AND_DOCK
Identical to the Cover demo, with one exception. If Create sees an infrared signal from an iRobot Home Base, it uses that signal to dock with the Home Base and recharge itself.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_SPOT_COVER

static final int DEMO_SPOT_COVER
Create covers an area around its starting position by spiraling outward, then inward.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_MOUSE

static final int DEMO_MOUSE
Create drives in search of a wall. Once a wall is found, Create drives along the wall, traveling around circumference of the room.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_DRIVE_FIGURE_EIGHT

static final int DEMO_DRIVE_FIGURE_EIGHT
Create continuously drives in a figure 8 pattern.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_WIMP

static final int DEMO_WIMP
Create drives forward when pushed from behind. If Create hits an obstacle while driving, it drives away from the obstacle.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_HOME

static final int DEMO_HOME
Create drives toward an iRobot Virtual Wall as long as the back and sides of the virtual wall receiver are blinded by black electrical tape.

A Virtual Wall emits infrared signals that Create sees with its Omnidirectional Infrared Receiver, located on top of the bumper.

If you want Create to home in on a Virtual Wall, cover all but a small opening in the front of the infrared receiver with black electrical tape.

Create spins to locate a virtual wall, then drives toward it. Once Create hits the wall or another obstacle, it stops.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_TAG

static final int DEMO_TAG
Identical to the Home demo, except Create drives into multiple virtual walls by bumping into one, turning around, driving to the next virtual wall, bumping into it and turning around to bump into the next virtual wall.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_PACHEBEL

static final int DEMO_PACHEBEL
Create plays the notes of Pachelbel's Canon in sequence when cliff sensors are activated.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEMO_BANJO

static final int DEMO_BANJO
Create plays a note of a chord for each of its four cliff sensors. Select the chord using the bumper, as follows:
  • No bumper: G major.
  • Right/left bumper: D major 7
  • Both bumpers (center): C major

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Method Detail

drive

void drive(int velocity,
           int radius)
This command controls Create's drive wheels. It takes two arguments. The first specifies the average velocity of the drive wheels in millimeters per second (mm/s). The next specifies the radius in millimeters at which the Create will turn. The longer radii make the Create drive straighter, while the shorter radii make the Create turn more. The radius is measured from the center of the turning circle to the center of the Create. A Drive command with a positive velocity and a positive radius makes the Create drive forward while turning toward the left. A negative radius makes the Create turn toward the right. Special cases for the radius make the Create turn in place or drive straight, as specified below. A negative velocity makes the Create drive backward.

NOTE: Internal and environmental restrictions may prevent the Create from accurately carrying out some drive commands. For example, it may not be possible for the Create to drive at full speed in an arc with a large radius of curvature.

  • Available in modes: Safe or Full
  • Changes mode to: No Change

Special values for Radius:

  • Straight = 32768 or 32767 = hex 8000 or 7FFF or DRIVE_STRAIGHT
  • Turn in place clockwise = hex FFFF or DRIVE_TURN_IN_PLACE_CLOCKWISE
  • Turn in place counter-clockwise = hex 0001 or DRIVE_TURN_IN_PLACE_COUNTER_CLOCKWISE

Parameters:
velocity - -500 - 500 mm/s
radius - -2000 - 2000 mm, or special cases

driveDirect

void driveDirect(int rightVelocity,
                 int leftVelocity)
This command lets you control the forward and backward motion of the Create's drive wheels independently. It takes two arguments. The first specifies the velocity of the right wheel in millimeters per second (mm/s). The next specifies the velocity of the left wheel. A positive velocity makes that wheel drive forward, while a negative velocity makes it drive backward.

Parameters:
rightVelocity - Right wheel velocity (-500 - 500 mm/s)
leftVelocity - Left wheel velocity (-500 - 500 mm/s)

stop

void stop()
Send a driveDirect command with 0, 0 for each wheel, stopping the Create.

getAccumulatedAngle

int getAccumulatedAngle()
Return the total angle the Create has rotated since this instance was created. This accumulation is done every time the angle sensor value is read from the Create. This value is not totally accurate but can be a general indication of what angle the Create is at.

Returns:
the total angle the Create has rotated in degrees

getAccumulatedDistance

int getAccumulatedDistance()
Return the total distance the Create has travelled since this instance was created. Not totally accurate, and is accumulated every time the distance sensor value is read from the Create.

Returns:
the total distance the Create has rotated in millimeters

getAngle

int getAngle()
The angle in degrees that iRobot Create has turned since the angle was last requested. Counter-clockwise angles are positive and clockwise angles are negative. If the value is not polled frequently enough, it is capped at its minimum or maximum.

Range: -32768 - 32767

NOTE: Create uses wheel encoders to measure distance and angle. If the wheels slip, the actual distance or angle traveled may differ from Create's measurements.

Returns:
the angle the Create has turned since last requested in degrees

getDistance

int getDistance()
The distance that Create has traveled in millimeters since the distance it was last requested is sent as a signed 16-bit value, high byte first. This is the same as the sum of the distance traveled by both wheels divided by two. Positive values indicate travel in the forward direction; negative values indicate travel in the reverse direction. If the value is not polled frequently enough, it is capped at its minimum or maximum.

Range: -32768 - 32767

Returns:
the distance the Create has traveled since last requested in millimeters

getRequestedVelocity

int getRequestedVelocity()
The velocity most recently requested with a Drive command is returned.

Range: -500 - 500 mm/s

Returns:
velocity set with last motion command, in mm/sec

getRequestedRadius

int getRequestedRadius()
The radius most recently requested with a Drive command is returned.

Range: -32768 - 32767 mm

Returns:
radius set with last motion command, in mm

getRequestedLeftVelocity

int getRequestedLeftVelocity()
The velocity most recently requested with a Drive command is returned.

Range: -500 - 500 mm/s

Returns:
left wheel velocity set with last motion command, in mm/sec

getRequestedRightVelocity

int getRequestedRightVelocity()
The right wheel velocity most recently requested with a Drive Direct command is returned.

Range: -500 - 500 mm/s

Returns:
right wheel velocity set with last motion command, in mm/sec

getHeading

int getHeading()
The current heading of the Create in degrees. This is an addition to the normal Create sensors and is what might be returned from a gyroscope or compass sensor.

Range: 0 - 359

NOTE: This method is not available on a real Create.

Returns:
current heading of the Create in degrees

isWall

boolean isWall()
The state of the wall sensor, true if there is a wall.

Returns:
true if there is a wall to right of Create

getWallSignal

int getWallSignal()
The strength of the wall sensor's signal is returned.

Range: 0-4095

Returns:
strength of the wall sensor's signal

isBumpLeft

boolean isBumpLeft()
Return true if the left bumper is pressed.

Returns:
true if the left bumper is pressed

isBumpRight

boolean isBumpRight()
Return true if the right bumper is pressed.

Returns:
true if the right bumper is pressed

waitAngle

void waitAngle(int degrees)
Cause the Java execution to pause until the Create has travelled to a delta of degrees. This command assumes that the robot is already moving/turning already. If not, then this command will never return, as this method will not return until the robot has rotated degrees. The state of the Create will not be affected, this means that if you expect the robot to stop after waiting degrees of turn, then you will need to send the Create the stop command.

create.driveDirect(100,-100);
waitAngle(90);
create.stop()

Note: this method samples the Create every 50ms.

Parameters:
degrees -
Throws:
OvercurrentException - if an overcurrent is detected.

waitAngle

void waitAngle(int degrees,
               long timeout)
               throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Cause the Java execution to pause until the Create has travelled to a delta of degrees or the specified timeout has expired. The state of the Create will not be affected, this means that if you expect the robot to stop after waiting degrees of turn, then you will need to send the Create the stop command.

create.driveDirect(100,-100);
waitAngle(90);
create.stop()

Note: this method samples the Create every 50ms.

Parameters:
degrees -
timeout - length of time to wait in milliseconds
Throws:
OvercurrentException - if an overcurrent is detected.
java.lang.InterruptedException

Throws:

                  throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Pause Java execution until the Create has travelled mms or the specified timeout has expired.

timeout - length of time to wait in milliseconds

getInfraredByte

int getInfraredByte()
This value identifies the IR byte currently being received by iRobot Create. A value of 255 indicates that no IR byte is being received. These bytes include those sent by the Roomba Remote, the Home Base, Create robots using the Send IR command, and user-created devices.

Range: 0 - 255

Returns:
One of IRobotCreateConstants.INFRARED_BYTE_*

getBatteryCapacity

int getBatteryCapacity()
The estimated charge capacity of Create's battery in milliamphours (mAh). Note that this value is inaccurate if you are using the alkaline battery pack.

Range: 0 - 65535

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Returns:
estimated charge capacity of Create's battery in mAh

getBatteryCharge

int getBatteryCharge()
The current charge of Create's battery in milliamp-hours (mAh). The charge value decreases as the battery is depleted during running and increases when the battery is charged.

Note that this value will not be accurate if you are using the alkaline battery pack.

Range: 0 - 65535

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Returns:
current charge of Create's battery in mAh

Returns:
One of CHARGING_STATE*

getCurrent

int getCurrent()
The current in milliamps (mA) flowing into or out of Create's battery. Negative currents indicate that the current is flowing out of the battery, as during normal running. Positive currents indicate that the current is flowing into the battery, as during charging.

Range: -32768 - 32767

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Returns:
current flowing into or out of Create's battery, in mA

Range: 0 - 65535

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Returns:
voltage of Create's battery in mV

leds

void leds(boolean powerLedOn,
          boolean playLedOn,
          boolean advanceLedOn)
This command controls the LEDs on Create. The state of the power Play and Advance LEDs is specified by true or false. Power led on will use full green to match other LEDs.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
powerLedOn -
playLedOn -
advanceLedOn -

leds

void leds(int powerColor,
          int powerIntensity,
          boolean playLedOn,
          boolean advanceLedOn)
This command controls the LEDs on Create. The state of the Play and Advance LEDs is specified by true or false. The power LED is specified by two values: one for the color and the other for the intensity.

Advance and Play use green LEDs. false = off, true = on

Power uses a bicolor (red/green) LED. The intensity and color of this LED can be controlled with 8-bit resolution.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
powerColor - Power LED Color (0 - 255) 0 = green, 255 = red. Intermediate values are intermediate colors (orange, yellow, etc).
powerIntensity - Power LED Intensity (0 - 255) 0 = off, 255 = full intensity. Intermediate values are intermediate intensities.
playLedOn -
advanceLedOn -

lowSideDrivers

void lowSideDrivers(boolean lowSideDriver0On,
                    boolean lowSideDriver1On,
                    boolean lowSideDriver2On)
This command lets you control the three low side drivers. The state of each driver is specified by true or false. Low side drivers 0 and 1 can provide up to 0.5A of current. Low side driver 2 can provide up to 1.5 A of current. If too much current is requested, the current is limited and the overcurrent flag is set (sensor packet 14).

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
lowSideDriver0On -
lowSideDriver1On -
lowSideDriver2On -

pwmLowSideDrivers

void pwmLowSideDrivers(int lowSideDriver0DutyCycle,
                       int lowSideDriver1DutyCycle,
                       int lowSideDriver2DutyCycle)
This command lets you control the three low side drivers with variable power. You specify the PWM duty cycle for the low side driver (max 128). For example, if you want to control a driver with 25% of battery voltage, choose a duty cycle of 128 * 25% = 32.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
lowSideDriver0DutyCycle - Duty cycle for low side driver 0 (0 - 128)
lowSideDriver1DutyCycle - Duty cycle for low side driver 1 (0 - 128)
lowSideDriver2DutyCycle - Duty cycle for low side driver 2 (0 - 128)

sendIr

void sendIr(int byteValue)
This command sends the requested byte out of low side driver 1 (pin 23 on the Cargo Bay Connector), using the format expected by iRobot Create's IR receiver. You must use a preload resistor (suggested value: 100 ohms) in parallel with the IR LED and its resistor in order turn it on.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
byteValue - Byte value to send (0 - 255)

digitalOutputs

void digitalOutputs(boolean pin0High,
                    boolean pin1High,
                    boolean pin2High)
This command controls the state of the 3 digital output pins on the 25 pin Cargo Bay Connector. The digital outputs can provide up to 20 mA of current.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
pin0High -
pin1High -
pin2High -

getCargoBayAnalogSignal

int getCargoBayAnalogSignal()
The 10-bit value of the analog input on the 25-pin Cargo Bay Connector is returned, high byte first. 0 = 0 volts; 1023 = 5 volts. The analog input is on pin 4.

Range: 0 - 1023

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Returns:
value of the Cargo Bay Connector analog input

cover

void cover()
Create attempts to cover an entire room using a combination of behaviors, such as random bounce, wall following, and spiraling.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

coverAndDock

void coverAndDock()
Identical to the Cover demo, with one exception. If Create sees an infrared signal from an iRobot Home Base, it uses that signal to dock with the Home Base and recharge itself.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

demo

void demo(int demoType)
This command starts the requested built-in demo.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
demoType - one IRobotCreateConstants.DEMO_*

spot

void spot()
Create covers an area around its starting position by spiraling outward, then inward.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

full

void full()
This command gives you complete control over Create by putting the OI into Full mode, and turning off the cliff, wheel-drop and internal charger safety features. That is, in Full mode, Create executes any command that you send it, even if the internal charger is plugged in, or the robot senses a cliff or wheel drop.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

safe

void safe()
This command puts the OI into Safe mode, enabling user control of Create. It turns off all LEDs. The OI can be in Passive, Safe, or Full mode to accept this command.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

getOiMode

int getOiMode()
Create's connection to the Home Base and Internal Charger are returned as individual bits, as below.

Returns:
One of OI_MODE_*

getSongNumber

int getSongNumber()
The currently selected OI song is returned.

Range: 0-15

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Returns:
number of currently selected song

playSong

void playSong(int songNumber)
This command lets you select a song to play from the songs added to iRobot Create using the Song command. You must add one or more songs to Create using the Song command in order for the Play command to work. Also, this command does not work if a song is already playing. Wait until a currently playing song is done before sending this command. Note that the "song playing" sensor packet can be used to check whether Create is ready to accept this command.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
songNumber - The number of the song Create is to play.

song

void song(int songNumber,
          int[] notesAndDurations)
This command lets you specify up to sixteen songs to the OI that you can play at a later time. Each song is associated with a song number. The Play command uses the song number to identify your song selection. Each song can contain up to sixteen notes. Each note is associated with a note number that uses MIDI note definitions and a duration that is specified in fractions of a second.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
songNumber - (0 - 15) The song number associated with the specific song. If you send a second Song command, using the same song number, the old song is overwritten.
notesAndDurations - every even index represents a note, every odd index is the duration of that note. The pitch of the musical note Create will play, according to the MIDI note numbering scheme. The lowest musical note that Create will play is Note #31. Create considers all musical notes outside the range of NOTE_FIRSTG - NOTE_LAST (31 - 127) as rest notes, and will make no sound during the duration of those notes.

The duration of a musical note, in increments of 1/64th of a second. Example: a half-second long musical note has a duration value of 32

song

void song(int songNumber,
          int[] notesAndDurations,
          int startIndex,
          int length)
This command lets you specify up to sixteen songs to the OI that you can play at a later time. Each song is associated with a song number. The Play command uses the song number to identify your song selection. Each song can contain up to sixteen notes. Each note is associated with a note number that uses MIDI note definitions and a duration that is specified in fractions of a second.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
songNumber - (0 - 15) The song number associated with the specific song. If you send a second Song command, using the same song number, the old song is overwritten.
notesAndDurations - every even index represents a note, every odd index is the duration of that note. The pitch of the musical note Create will play, according to the MIDI note numbering scheme. The lowest musical note that Create will play is Note #31. Create considers all musical notes outside the range of NOTE_FIRSTG - NOTE_LAST (31 - 127) as rest notes, and will make no sound during the duration of those notes.

The duration of a musical note, in increments of 1/64th of a second. Example: a half-second long musical note has a duration value of 32

startIndex -
length - number of bytes to send from notesAndDuration, must be even number

waitButtonPressed

void waitButtonPressed(boolean playButton,
                       boolean beep)
Pause Java execution until either the play or the advance button is pressed. While waiting, blink the LED next to the desired button.

Note: not currently implemented in Emulator.

Parameters:
playButton - If true wait for the play button, otherwise wait for the advance button

setIBumpListenerPeriod

void setIBumpListenerPeriod(long period)
Set how often the bump sensors are checked in order to notify any IBumpListener's.

Note: period is ignored by Emulator.

Parameters:
period - time in milliseconds between checks. Must be greater than 15 msec.

setIWallListenerPeriod

void setIWallListenerPeriod(long period)
Set how often the wall sensor is checked in order to notify any IWallListener's.

Note: period is ignored by Emulator.

Parameters:
period - time in milliseconds between checks. Must be greater than 15 msec.
